articles.headline: At Euro Talks, a Calm Arm-Twister From the U.S.
articles.snippet: Lael Brainard, a Treasury under secretary who is America’s top financial diplomat, is trying to coax European leaders to contribute to a financial firewall.
articles.abstract: Lael Brainard, a Treasury under secretary who is America’s top financial diplomat, is trying to coax European leaders to contribute to a financial firewall.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The world’s financiers and finance ministers have descended on the annual forum in Davos, Switzerland, at another perilous moment, with the sovereign debt woes in Europe sapping strength from emerging markets and threatening global growth.

articles.headline: Romney Paid More Than He Owed
articles.snippet: The tax code of the United States is far too complicated, if the errors in Republican Mitt Romney’s tax returns are any indication.
articles.abstract: The tax code of the United States is far too complicated, if the errors in Republican Mitt Romney’s tax returns are any indication.
articles.lead_paragraph: Mitt Romney’s tax returns tell us some things about him. They tell us a lot more about the sad state of the tax laws in this country.

articles.headline: Israel Senses Bluffing in Iran’s Threats of Retaliation
articles.snippet: As Israel’s political and military leaders weigh options to stop Iran’s nuclear program, many are guided by an assessment that an attack is unlikely to set off widespread conflict.
articles.abstract: As Israel’s political and military leaders weigh options to stop Iran’s nuclear program, many are guided by an assessment that an attack is unlikely to set off widespread conflict.
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Israeli intelligence estimates, backed by academic studies, have cast doubt on the widespread assumption that a military strike on Iranian nuclear facilities would set off a catastrophic set of events like a regional conflagration, widespread acts of terrorism and sky-high oil prices.

articles.headline: For $2 a Star, an Online Retailer Gets 5-Star Product Reviews
articles.snippet: Agencies like the Federal Trade Commission have been trying to crack down on online product reviews that do not disclose the connection between a merchant and the person doling out the praise.
articles.abstract: Agencies like the Federal Trade Commission have been trying to crack down on online product reviews that do not disclose the connection between a merchant and the person doling out the praise.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the brutal world of online commerce, where a competing product is just a click away, retailers need all the juice they can get to close a sale.

articles.headline: For Greece, the Outlook Is Still Grim
articles.snippet: A new analysis suggests the nation’s economic condition is worsening, throwing a wrench into talks meant to pave the way for more financial support.
articles.abstract: A new analysis suggests the nation’s economic condition is worsening, throwing a wrench into talks meant to pave the way for more financial support.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Even as Greece tries to convince creditors that its debt-reduction efforts are on track, gloomy new International Monetary Fund forecasts about its long-term economy are threatening to derail talks meant to secure the nation’s next big installment of bailout funds.

articles.headline: Romney Stays on the Offense With Gingrich
articles.snippet: The competition between Mitt Romney and Newt Gingrich dominated the last debate before the Florida primary, as the two angrily traded charges on Thursday over their immigration policies and financial holdings.
articles.abstract: The competition between Mitt Romney and Newt Gingrich dominated the last debate before the Florida primary, as the two angrily traded charges on Thursday over their immigration policies and financial holdings.
articles.lead_paragraph: JACKSONVILLE, Fla. — Mitt Romney, facing his greatest challenge of the campaign so far, relentlessly pressed Newt Gingrich on Thursday night in their final debate before the Florida primary, seeking to regain the offensive against an insurgent challenge that has shaken his claim to inevitability.
articles.byline: By Jim Rutenberg and Jeff Zeleny

articles.headline: Energy Tax Breaks Proposed, Despite Waning Support for Subsidies
articles.snippet: Wind and solar companies say they need more government support to be competitive. But in Washington, there’s little enthusiasm for more subsidies.
articles.abstract: Wind and solar companies say they need more government support to be competitive. But in Washington, there’s little enthusiasm for more subsidies.
articles.lead_paragraph: Assisted by technological innovation and years of subsidies, the cost of wind and solar power has fallen sharply — so much so that the two industries say that they can sometimes deliver cleaner electricity at prices competitive with power made from fossil fuels.

articles.headline: Big Victory on Internet Buoys Lobby
articles.snippet: With their success against antipiracy legislation in Congress, the Internet industry and its allies are weighing their future as a political force.
articles.abstract: With their success against antipiracy legislation in Congress, the Internet industry and its allies are weighing their future as a political force.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — The unlikely coalition of companies and consumer groups that last week helped quash antipiracy legislation on Capitol Hill is now weighing the future of what might be called lobbying 2.0. Can the Internet industry, along with legions of newly politicized Web users, be a new force in Washington? And if so, what else can they all agree upon?

articles.headline: Gingrich Stuck to Caustic Path in Ethics Battles
articles.snippet: Newt Gingrich used ethics issues to make political gains from the beginning of his career, but in the end ethics issues helped topple him from power in the House.
articles.abstract: Newt Gingrich used ethics issues to make political gains from the beginning of his career, but in the end ethics issues helped topple him from power in the House.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Newt Gingrich had an urgent warning for conservatives: Jim Wright, the Democratic speaker of the House, was out to destroy America.

articles.headline: For Ford, Three Years of Profit in a Row
articles.snippet: The automaker’s earnings for 2011 were the largest in 13 years after a one-time gain in the fourth quarter.
articles.abstract: The automaker’s earnings for 2011 were the largest in 13 years after a one-time gain in the fourth quarter.
articles.lead_paragraph: DEARBORN, Mich. — The Ford Motor Company reported its third consecutive full-year profit on Friday and its largest in 13 years, ensuring its hourly workers one of the biggest profit-sharing bonuses in the company’s history.

articles.headline: Growth Accelerates, but U.S. Has Lots of Ground to Make Up
articles.snippet: Whether the American economy, which grew last quarter at its fastest pace in a year and a half, can sustain that momentum is critical to millions of people out of work.
articles.abstract: Whether the American economy, which grew last quarter at its fastest pace in a year and a half, can sustain that momentum is critical to millions of people out of work.
articles.lead_paragraph: The American economy picked up a little steam last quarter, growing at its fastest pace in a year and a half. Whether it can sustain that momentum is critical to millions of Americans out of work — and perhaps President Obama’s re-election chances.
